summary: See documents of a $6.4 billion lawsuit filed in federal bankruptcy court that claims J.P. Morgan bankers abetted Ponzi-scheme financier Bernard Madoff.

summary: See key events in the case of disgraced financier Bernard Madoff.

headline: Super Bowl Home Showdown -- Poll
summary: The big game is Sunday, and here are two homes offering comfortable retreats for fans. Vote for your favorite. --Sushil Cheema, 02/04/11

summary: Corrections & Amplifications for Feb. 4, 2011

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance: Top Stories for Feb. 4, 2011

headline: Selling to Baby Boomers
summary: From cars to music to product packaging, companies have strived to accommodate baby boomers. See a short timeline of products and trends.

headline: Knicks' Late SurgeDoesn't Hold Up
summary: Amar'e Stoudemire and the Knicks suffered what might have been one of the most frustrating losses of the season.

headline: Student-Loan Default Rates Worsen
summary: The increase reflects a tough job market for recent college graduates and provides new fodder that for-profit colleges, which posted the highest default rates, need better policing.

headline: Court Overrules Canada's Support of Globalive
summary: The Federal Court of Canada has overturned the government's 2009 decision to allow Globalive Wireless Management ownership structure to stand and offer mobile phone services, dealing a blow to wireless competition in the country and the government's goal of achieving cheaper mobile phone pricing.

headline: U.S. Mulls Big Pipeline Decision
summary: Concerns over pipeline safety threaten to complicate the relationship between the U.S. and its largest petroleum supplier.

headline: Mayor Hits Back at Parents
summary: Mayor Bloomberg had strong criticism for parents and elected officials who spoke out at this week's meetings on the city's plans to close low-performing schools.

headline: Noonan: Ronald Reagan at 100
summary: Being a good man helped him become a great one.

headline: Bahrainis Hold Protest at Egyptian Embassy
summary: Hundreds of Bahrainis gathered in front of the Egyptian embassy in the capital Manama, in a rally organized in solidarity with Egypt's pro-democracy movement that also lent a voice to Bahrain's own opposition.

headline: Protests Wrack Cairo
summary: Since late January, antigovernment demonstrators have swarmed the streets of Cairo, calling for President Hosni Mubarak to step down and at times clashing with the president's supporters. Much of the action has centered on Tahrir Square.

headline: Regulators Close 2 Georgia Banks
summary: The failures of American Trust Bank and North Georgia Bank bring the total number of failures in the U.S. this year to 13.

headline: The Tax Bowl
summary: Roethlisberger vs. Rodgers vs. Romo.

headline: The Super Bowl's Endorsement Factory
summary: Scenes from Radio Row in Dallas, from Eli Manning hawking cookies to Joe Montana promoting Oreos.

headline: After Cutting Prices, 3 IPOs Rise
summary: BG Medicine rose 15%, Endocyte gained 29%, and MedQuist Holdings ended up 13%. A fourth, Trunkbow International, declined.

headline: Categoric Brunch
summary: Brunch at Bistro de la Gare in Greenwich Village is divided into three categories: American, Mexican and Mediterranean.

headline: The Tax Bowl
summary: About how much do the NFL's top players make and pay in taxes?

headline: Trade Assumes Status-Quo for the Dollar
summary: Activity in normally sleepy contracts on the PowerShares DB US Dollar Bearish Fund surged to a record Friday, thanks to a giant bet that the dollar isn't likely to make any drastic moves until at least autumn.

headline: Ford's Answer to the European Sport Sedan
summary: With the 2012 Focus Titanium Sedan, Ford is offering a realistic -- if underpowered -- competitor to small Audis and BMWs, writes Dan Neil.

headline: Blackouts Hit Brazil's Northeast States
summary: At least eight northeastern Brazilian states lost power Thursday night after problems at an electric substation knocked out transmission lines and temporarily shut down generation capacity, disrupting air travel for a few hours during the busy summer season

headline: Higher Prices Help Tyson Foods
summary: Tyson Foods' fiscal-first-quarter earnings rose 86% as the meatpacker benefited from stronger prices and sales volume. The company said domestic food inflation will likely overtake U.S. government forecasts as crop and animal feed prices continue to rise.

headline: For J.P. Morgan, Suit Brings Reputational Risk
summary: J.P. Morgan Chase potentially faces reputational damage, and maybe even more legal woes, from allegations leveled in a lawsuit by the trustee seeking to recoup losses for Bernard Madoff's victims.

headline: Sotomayor, Unplugged
summary: During a speech at the University of Chicago Law School, the Supreme Court Justice took issue with the positions of some of her colleagues on the bench.

headline: Hundreds Join Protests in Jordan
summary: Hundreds of Jordanians staged peaceful antigovernment protests, urging the country's newly-appointed prime minister to make good on promises of political reform.

headline: Actelion Rebuts Investor's Criticism
summary: Actelion's board shrugged off criticism from investor Elliott Advisors, saying it is backing its leadership and will remain independent as Europe's largest biotech firm.

headline: Gold Futures Ebb
summary: Gold prices fell slightly as a mixed U.S. jobs report and continued unease about turmoil in Egypt did little to spur new refuge demand for the precious metal.

headline: Photos of the Day
summary: In Friday's pictures, Oklahoma digs out from a snowstorm, a man makes traditional valenki footwear in Russia, the Saudi Hawks aerobatic team streaks by and more.

headline: DaVita to Buy DSI Renal for $690M
summary: DaVita agreed to buy dialysis-center operator DSI Renal for about $690 million, looking to expand geographically.

headline: Tea Party Unlikely to Derail Patriot Act Renewal
summary: The Patriot Act as a good chance of being reauthorized, even as the surge of the tea party brought to Washington a new legion of lawmakers suspicious of government power. The first test comes this month.

headline: Copper Settles at Record High
summary: Copper futures ended at a record high, boosted by a drop in the U.S. unemployment rate and speculation that demand would continue to outpace demand.

headline: Banco Popular Profit Drops 23%
summary: Banco Popular Espanol said its net profit fell 23% in 2010, hit by provisions to cover loan losses in Spain and Portugal.

headline: Sweden Sells $2.9 Billion Nordea Stake
summary: The Swedish government sold 255 million shares in Nordea Bank in its first post-re-election sale of state-owned corporate assets.

headline: Photos of the Day
summary: In today's pictures, Oklahoma digs out from a snowstorm, a man makes traditional valenki footwear in Russia, the Saudi Hawks aerobatic team streaks by and more.

headline: Aetna's Profit Rises 30%
summary: Aetna's fourth-quarter earnings rose 30% as the health insurer's medical-claims costs declined, though revenue from premiums fell.

headline: Popular Loss Widens
summary: Puerto Rico's Popular reported a wider fourth-quarter loss, as it set aside more funds to cover potential loan losses and took a charge related to loan sales.

headline: Hungary Blasts IMF Assessment
summary: Hungary harshly criticized the IMF for what it said was the fund's misleading assessment of the country, and it called on the IMF to publicly acknowledge it made an error about the country's 2010 budget assumptions.

headline: Cyclone Whips Northeast Australia
summary: A tropical cyclone that slammed into Australia's northeast coast overnight caused less damage than first feared, narrowly missing the major city of Cairns after thousands of residents fled amid warnings of monstrous waves and wild winds.

headline: Demonstrators Protest in Jordan
summary: Hundreds of Jordanians staged peaceful antigovernment protests on Friday, urging the country's newly-appointed prime minister to make good on promises of political reform

headline: European Stocks Gain
summary: European stocks ended higher, with utilities and financial stocks posting particularly strong gains, getting a lift from an unexpected decline in the U.S. unemployment rate.

headline: Investors Wait for Egypt 'Fog to Clear'
summary: Investors said they may hesitate before committing new money to the Middle East, including oil-rich Gulf Arab states, as a result of the political turmoil spreading across the region.

headline: Canada Job Growth Soars
summary: Canada's employment kicked off the year on a scorching note as the economy churned out about 4.5 times more new jobs than expected.

headline: Irish Party Seeks Bank-Debt Plan
summary: Ireland's main opposition party Fine Gael said the next government would be forced to "unilaterally" restructure the debt of Irish banks if a deal cannot be reached on senior bond holders sharing the cost of recapitalizing Ireland's insolvent banks.

headline: Fortune Brands Posts Higher Profit, Sales
summary: Fortune Brands posted higher fourth-quarter earnings, aided by sales growth in all three of its units.

headline: Complete Production Services, Eastern Virginia Bankshares: Biggest Price Decliners (CPX, EVBS)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Decliners.

headline: NeoPhotonics, JDS Uniphase: Biggest Price Gainers (NPTN, JDSU)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Gainers.

headline: Shumway Capital to Cash Out Investors
summary: Shumway Capital Partners is planning to return all of its external capital to investors by the end of the first quarter, founder Chris Shumway said in a letter to investors on Friday.

headline: Giffords's Husband to Fly on Shuttle
summary: Astronaut Mark Kelly, the husband of wounded Rep. Gabrielle Giffords, has decided to fly on a space mission in April.

headline: U.K. Politicians Clash Over Economy
summary: U.K. Prime Minister David Cameron's government has clashed with the opposition Labour party over economic policy as it sought to face down criticism that ministers had no plan to propel the recovery.

headline: Egypt Girds for Massive Protest
summary: Tens of thousands of protesters filled central Cairo's Tahrir Square Friday, deepening the standoff with a regime that continues to reject their demand that Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak step down.

headline: Oil Prices Boost Rosneft's Profit
summary: Rosneft, Russia's largest oil producer, said fourth-quarter net profit rose 83% from a year earlier on higher oil prices and greater crude oil production.

headline: Pakistan Cricketers to Face Charges
summary: Three leading Pakistan cricket players face criminal charges in Britain in the latest fallout from an alleged betting scandal that has rocked the genteel sport.

headline: Idaho's Crapo Takes Aim at Budget
summary: Idaho Republican Sen. Mike Crapo is emerging as a pivotal player in Congress's attempt to craft a solution to long-term fiscal woes.

headline: The Nursery Admission Scramble
summary: Around this time of year, Indian parents brace themselves for fierce competition as they try to get their children admitted to nursery school. Some snapshots.

headline: India This Week
summary: Some snapshots of events that were in news this week

headline: Swedish Truck Makers Suffer Production Woes
summary: Sweden's truck makers, which shed workers and curbed capacity during the economic downturn as sales dwindled, are encountering problems as they ramp up production now that demand has returned.

headline: Lower Your Tax Bill Using Lesser-Known Breaks
summary: Payment of house rent and medical expenses can be deducted from your tax liability, says Shefali Anand, India personal finance writer.

headline: Las Vegas Sands Posts Profit
summary: Las Vegas Sands stormed back to profit in the fourth quarter, fueled by heady growth in the Chinese gambling enclave of Macau and a new $5.5 billion casino in Singapore.

headline: PTT to Keep Australian Licenses
summary: Thailand's PTT Exploration & Production won't have its Australian oil licences revoked after cooperating with authorities and improving its operations following the 2009 Montara oil spill.

headline: Report: India's Spectrum-Allotment Process was "Wrong"
summary: A retired judge examining the allocation of telecom licenses and bandwidth by India's Department of Telecommunications from 2001 to 2009 has said all procedures adopted since 2003 were "wrong."

headline: Fuji Heavy Sees Sales Growth
summary: Fuji Heavy Industries, maker of Subarus, returned to profitability as growth in overseas sales offset the strong yen.

headline: Japan 10-Year Yield Near 2-Month High
summary: Japan's benchmark 10-year government bond yield hit 1.285% amid increasing optimism over the U.S. economy that sent Treasury yields higher.

headline: TD Ameritrade Settles SEC Case
summary: TD Ameritrade agreed to settle U.S. civil charges for failing to properly supervise brokers who sold shares of the Reserve Yield Plus Fund, which "broke the buck" during the financial crisis of 2008.

headline: Fine Over Bug in 'Quant' Program
summary: A unit of French insurer AXA agreed to pay $242 million to settle fraud accusations by the SEC that it hid from clients a software glitch in a quantitative investment model.

headline: Cipla's Net Profit Falls 19%
summary: Cipla, one of India's top four drug makers by sales, said its net profit for the October-December period fell to 2.33 billion rupees ($51.1 million), missing analysts' estimates, as the company was hurt by higher operating costs and an unfavorable local currency.

headline: Buddhist Monk Aided Thai Central Bank
summary: Bua Yannasampanno, a hermit Buddhist monk who died Sunday in Thailand at the age of 97, left all the gold in his custody to Thailand's central bank.

headline: Trichet Sees Inflation Spike as Short-Lived
summary: ECB President Jean-Claude Trichet reined in his previously hawkish remarks, expressing confidence that inflationary pressures in the euro area will abate by the end of the year.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Registers a Profit
summary: Weyerhaeuser posted a fourth-quarter profit as the timber-products company's revenue and margins improved.

headline: Constellation Energy's Earnings Fall
summary: Constellation Energy's fourth-quarter earnings fell 96%, compared with a year-earlier quarter that included a gain of $7.45 billion from the sale of its stake in a nuclear joint venture.

headline: India's NHPC Gets Clearance for Hydroelectric Projects
summary: An expert panel has cleared state-owned NHPC's plans to set up two hydroelectric projects in India's north-east worth $2.47 billion.

headline: Investors Stand Poised to Seize on Strong (or Weak) Jobs Data
summary: The closely watched nonfarm payroll data from the Labor Department are set to be released at 8:30 a.m. Eastern time, before the market opens in New York. This could give just the ballast needed to propel major stock indexes beyond recent multiyear highs.

headline: India Shares End Sharply Lower on Profit-Taking
summary: Indian shares broke a two-day positive run to close sharply lower, as nervous investors used recent gains to take profits, especially in large-cap stocks such as Reliance Industries and ICICI Bank.

headline: Europe's TV Market for Sports Faces Turmoil
summary: Broadcasters of English Premier League soccer and other big-ticket sports and entertainment events could soon be barred from carving up the EU into differently priced national markets.

headline: Tokyo Buoys Asian Shares
summary: Most Asian markets advanced Friday, with Japanese stocks buoyed by a proposed merger between Nippon Steel Corp. and Sumitomo Metal Industries. The Nikkei rose 1.1%.

headline: Corporate Jets vs. Scheduled First Class -- How They Compare
summary: Corporate jets can beat scheduled first class for efficiency, but higher prices and a lack of luxury can be a drawback

headline: India's Weekend Movie
summary: Director Sudhir Mishra's 'Yeh Saali Zindagi' featuring Arunoday Singh, Chitrangada Singh and Irrfan Khan hits Indian screens Friday. Some snapshots.

headline: Halifax: U.K House Prices Rise
summary: U.K. house prices posted a surprise gain in January compared with December, mortgage lender Halifax said, attributing the rise to a monthly fluctuation rather than a significant change in market conditions.

headline: India in Pictures
summary: Children playing near the India-Pakistan border, former telecom minister A.Raja outside a court in New Delhi, devotees on the banks of the Ganges river and more.

headline: Mayor Looks in Mirror, Likes What He Sees
summary: Mayor Michael Bloomberg on Thursday confessed he harbors an incurable crush on ... Mayor Michael Bloomberg.

headline: Deutsche Bank's Way With Numbers
summary: Deutsche Bank managed to post record revenue of $10.2 billion for the fourth quarter, but all is not quite what it seems.

headline: New Ways to Gauge TV Ads
summary: The race for new ways to measure the impact of television commercials is heating up. TiVo and others are ramping their competition with Nielsen.

headline: Viacom Net Falls, Hurt by Weak DVDs
summary: Viacom profit fell 12%, reflecting a slide in DVD sales. Cable-TV and box-office revenues were strong.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: John Heilemann, co-author of "Game Change," writing about President Obama's management style.

headline: Growing a Garden in the Great Hall
summary: Next week a team of young designers from the Brooklyn-based Situ Studio will fill the Brooklyn Museum's newly renovated entry with fantastic fungi.

headline: Moviemaker Ranged From Grizzlies to God
summary: Filmmaker Charles Sellier determined precisely what audiences wanted, then delivered it to them.

headline: School Meeting Draws Protest
summary: In Brooklyn, protesters laid bare the divide that has become central to the Bloomberg administration's education policy: whether failing schools should be fixed or closed.

headline: Cave-Dive 'Sanctum': 3-D Awe, Flat Script
summary: A powerful James Cameron production is almost drowned by weak dialogue and direction, says Joe Morgenstern. Meanwhile, Natalie Portman is betrayed by "The Other Woman."

headline: High Police Pay Fuels Nassau Squeeze
summary: If you're looking for one of the reasons why Nassau County spends so much, start with police pay. The average salary of a sworn police officer in Nassau last year was $107,000.

headline: Haiti Bows to Pressure to Pull Its Pick
summary: Haiti's electoral council eliminated a government-backed candidate in a March run-off election that will determine this earthquake-devastated country's next president.

headline: Egypt Girds for Showdown
summary: Egypt's government sought to address grievances by its opponents after bloody clashes in Cairo, but continued to resist demands that Mubarak step down immediately. In an ABC News interview, Mubarak said he can't leave now or the country will sink deeper into chaos.

headline: Price Premiums Grow for New Homes
summary: A reader asks why resale home prices are falling, while prices at new developments are on the rise

headline: Trustee: J.P. Morgan Abetted Madoff
summary: J.P. Morgan stood "at the very center" of Bernard Madoff's fraud, according to a lawsuit that reveals for the first time how bank employees' concerns allegedly went unheeded.

headline: Duane Sorenson's Portland Home
summary: For the founder of Stumptown Coffee, life on the top floor of a contemporary building in Portland, Ore. includes kids, microbrews and heavy metal records.

headline: Reagan's Level Field for World Trade
summary: In Judy Shelton's"The Wrong Way to Double Exports" (op-ed, Jan, 26), she states that "Ronald Reagan believed we could 'outproduce, outcompete and outsell anybody' without compromising the value of the dollar."

headline: The Price of Moral Purity
summary: "The Fair Trade Revolution" makes a case for fair dealing with farmers and producers on the far end of the supply chain—those in the remote villages and mountainsides of the developing world. Andrew Stark reviews.

headline: Airlines Won't Get Upgrade Funding
summary: A major aviation bill before the Senate doesn't include significant funding for new air-traffic control equipment, as U.S. airlines had hoped.

headline: Corot's Figures Without a Landscape
summary: The "L'armoire secrète" exhbition at the renovated Sammlung Oskar Reinhart "Am Römerholz" in Wintherthur focuses on the figures of French landscape artist Jean-Baptiste-Camille Corot.

headline: Super Bowl Ads: Who Will Score?
summary: Marketers are gambling $2.8 million to $3 million on 30-second ads on the Super Bowl broadcast.

headline: We Stand for Innovation and Enterprise as Always
summary: Your editorial "The Great Misallocators" (Jan. 26) misrepresents the policies and record of General Electric Co. and makes the incredible assertion that GE symbolizes a major reason that the U.S. has become less competitive.

headline: Health Foes Try Divergent Tactics
summary: States challenging the massive health-care law enacted last year are employing different tactics in their push for swift Supreme Court review of their legal cases.

headline: Seduced by Burgundy 2009
summary: The harvest of 2009 marks a substantial return to form for Burgundy's Côte d'Or. This is a year to enjoy the wines for what they are: luscious, sweet, rich and easy to drink.

headline: Council Hammers Wal-Mart at Hearing
summary: The City Council called a hearing to discuss the potential impact if Wal-Mart decides to open a store in New York City.

headline: Bernanke Denies Fed Is Stoking Inflation
summary: Bernanke said the recovery should gain speed this year, but continued support from the Fed is needed amid high unemployment and low inflation, shrugging off higher commodity prices.

headline: Pre-Revolutionary War Era Homes
summary: Homes in Pound Ridge, N.Y., Duxbury, Mass., and York, Maine.

headline: Richard Lea: Look Out Below!
summary: The idea of extinction by impact, which had been around since the 17th century, found a different reception in the age of the nuclear bomb.

headline: Tangled Tale of a Dakota Co-op
summary: A two-bedroom apartment has gone into contract at the Dakota for about $4.4 million. But the deal is caught up in legal measures taken by Dutch prosecutors, who say they have claims on the property.

headline: What's on Around Europe
summary: The Weekend Journal's guide to exhibitions, concerts and events across Europe.

headline: George Melloan: The States Can't Afford ObamaCare
summary: Their budgets will be crushed by the Medicaid expansions that the feds are forcing on them.

headline: Hamas, the Brotherhood and Egypt
summary: What the U.S. mistakes of 2006 can teach Arab democrats.

headline: Risks Lie Ahead for EU
summary: As the European Union holds a summit on the euro-zone debt crisis, there is calm—but also a widespread, though not universal, expectation in the financial markets that more storms lie ahead.

headline: The Barbarian from Small-Town Texas
summary: In the stories of Robert E. Howard, Tom Shippey finds an abundance of invention: temples of forgotten cults deep in the jungle, reanimated sorcerers and naked beauties offering immortality.

headline: Weather Pressures Strained Budgets
summary: Several big cities, including New York and Kansas City, Mo., have already exhausted their snow-removal budgets and are scrambling for additional funds, and many other cities and towns aren't far behind.

headline: Tip of the Day
summary: Two of the National Football League's most successful franchises, the Pittsburgh Steelers and Green Bay Packers, meet in Super Bowl XLV on Sunday.

headline: Algeria to Lift Limits on Liberty
summary: Algeria is to lift a state of emergency in force since the 1990s civil war, President Abdelaziz Bouteflika said, throwing a key concession to the opposition as it responds to unrest at home and in the rest of the Arab world.

headline: Andy to Say Goodbye to Yankees
summary: Pettitte's retirement news conference Friday will mark the end of an era defined by championships.

headline: Starwood Hotels Swings to Profit
summary: Starwood swung to a profit as the hotel operator and franchiser said it expects that growth to continue at a steady pace for the year, but that economic uncertainty remains.

headline: Costs Cloud Retail Outlook
summary: Many chain stores reported better-than-expected same-store sales for January, despite snowstorms that many feared would cool spending. Sales overall rose 4.2%. But rising costs cloud the spring outlook.

headline: UBS Makes Bid to Increase Bonus Pool
summary: UBS delayed payment of its bonuses after executives expressed concerns that the pending payouts would be inadequate to retain the top talent the Swiss bank has been hiring to rebuild its investment bank.

headline: Dante Meets Disney
summary: In the overwrought staging of "Francesca da Rimini" at the Paris Opera by director Giancarlo Del Monaco, Zandonai's opera is turned into a Pre-Raphaelite fantasy.

headline: Mortgage Bankers Miss out on Profits
summary: A year ago, in what seemed like a supreme irony, the Mortgage Bankers Association sold its headquarters at a big loss. On Thursday, insult was added to injury: The building's buyer has flipped it for a big profit.

headline: Deutsche Bank Seeks Commodity M&A
summary: Deutsche Bank said it is hunting for acquisitions in commodities trading, joining the scramble among investment banks to take advantage of the boom in raw-material prices as fixed-income trading cools. The German bank also confirmed a 54% drop in fourth-quarter net profit to €601 million.

headline: Hot Horns, Vital Organs ... and Brooke Shields
summary: This week's jazz calendar leads with the triple-sax attack of Ravi Coltrane, Dave Liebman and Joe Lovano. But let's not forget Brooke Shields's cabaret debut at Feinstein's.

headline: House GOP Offers Spending Plan
summary: House Republican leaders proposed cutting more than $30 billion from government spending for the remainder of the fiscal year, an opening shot in their first budget battle against President Obama.

headline: Israel Worries About Gas Pipeline
summary: Turmoil in Egypt is fanning concern in Israel that a new government in Cairo might shut down the natural-gas pipeline that fuels as much as one-fourth of Israel's electricity network.

headline: Argentine Comments Show Rift With U.S.
summary: Argentina's relations with the U.S. hit a new bump as the foreign minister suggested that a U.S.-sponsored police-training program was teaching oppressive tactics to members of the Buenos Aires police force.

headline: Mortgage Rates Hold Steady
summary: Rates on the 30-year fixed-rate home mortgage averaged 4.81% for the week ended Feb. 3, up just slightly from 4.80% last week

headline: Pressure on Mubarak Opens Rift With Allies
summary: President Barack Obama's showdown with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak has opened a rift with Saudi Arabia and United Arab Emirates, which fear the U.S. is opening the door for Islamist groups to gain influence.

headline: World Watch
summary: Here is a selection of news from around the world from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: Uptown Moms, a Downtown Queen
summary: Marshall Heyman attends a book launch uptown at Chanel and a boutique opening on lower Broadway.

headline: Tunisia Probes Protester Deaths
summary: Tunisia is aiming to bring to justice those responsible for the killing of 219 protesters during the uprising, but human-rights organizations warn it will be difficult challenging the country's fearsome secret police.

headline: Malcolm Forbes's N.Y. Townhouse Hits the Market
summary: A Manhattan townhouse owned by the family of Malcolm Forbes, the late chairman and editor in chief of Forbes magazine, has hit the market for $15.3 million.

headline: SEC Weighs IPO of 'Stockpiler'
summary: U.S. securities regulators are taking a closer look at plans by Nasdaq OMX Group to list companies whose business is stockpiling commodities like "rare earths."

headline: Robert McFarlane: Three Qualities That Made Reagan Great
summary: On his 100th birthday, it's worth recalling the character and leadership essential to presidential success.

headline: Neither Does He Spin
summary: Wilfred Sheed managed to make a drama critic look quite a bit like a human being.

headline: Heavy Metal Meets Toy Bunnies
summary: The highly urban, kid-friendly, utterly Portland, Ore., home of Stumptown Coffee's Duane Sorenson.

headline: Paying Homage With Humor
summary: It's hard to assess Tate Britain's claim that Susan Hiller is "one of the most influential artists of her generation." In a superficial way, you can trace influences in the titles of some of her work in the museum's big exhibition, but the arrow of influence often points in the other direction.

headline: No Inflation, but Prices Keep Rising
summary: I don't know about the rest of the small-business community, but the continuing decline in the price of homes, the increase in the price of food, appliances, utilities and group health insurance, the staggering debt attributed to the federal government and the financial burdens associated with many states and municipalities don't stimulate my economic outlook ("Economy Picks Up Steam, Output Returns to '07 Level," page one, Jan. 29).

headline: Shell Delays Alaska Plan
summary: Shell unveiled disappointing fourth-quarter results and said it is postponing a controversial plan to drill for oil in the Arctic waters off Alaska by a year, after U.S. regulators withdrew a key permit.

headline: Mellon Accused of Fake Trades
summary: Recently unsealed documents allege Bank of New York Mellon overcharged Virginia pension funds by at least $20 million.The allegations are part of a widening probe by state prosecutors.

headline: Weak Europe Weighs on Santander
summary: Spain's Banco Santander said its net profit fell 4.6% in the fourth quarter as lower income from Europe offset strong growth in the Americas and the U.K.

headline: Madoff Trustee, Mets Owners Seek to Unseal Suit
summary: The trustee seeking to recover money on behalf of Madoff's victims and lawyers for the Mets owners have asked a federal bankruptcy judge to unseal a lawsuit after negotiations to settle the case broke down.

headline: Just Don't Call It a Document
summary: A decade after introducing freedom of information laws, the EU is seeking to tighten them.

headline: Vodafone Chairman Should Aim High
summary: When Gerard Kleisterlee takes over as chairman in July, he will have plenty of work to do to boost the company's shares.

headline: Actelion Directors Asked to Quit
summary: Investment firm Elliott Advisors called for a boardroom overhaul at Actelion, launching a battle that could lead to the sale of Europe's largest biotech company.

headline: Voices Soften for Yemeni Ouster
summary: Opposition supporters flooded several blocks of the Yemeni capital, with protest leaders demanding President Ali Abdullah Saleh make good on promises of political and economic reform.
